0.00.text:
IN THE FIGHT TO SAVE
CALIFORNIA'S ENDANGERED CONDORS.

7.47.text:
Marcy: OTHER INTELLIGENT LIFE
IN THE UNIVERSE IS

12.75.text:
ABOUT HOW SLEEP WASHES TOXINS
FROM OUR BRAIN.

15.95.text:
AND A DIVE INTO THE OCEAN'S
TWILIGHT ZONE.

40.24.text: Announcer: SUPPORT FOR "QUEST" IS PROVIDED BY...

65.47.text:
"QUEST" IS A PROJECT
OF KQED SCIENCE.

89.62.text:
CONDORS CARRY
THE POWER OF THE WIND.

93.13.text:
THEY ALSO CARRY THE HONOR
AND THE POWER OF THE PEOPLE.

96.96.text:
Narrator: THE POWER
OF THE CONDOR WAS LEGENDARY

100.30.text:
TO THE NATIVE PEOPLE
OF CALIFORNIA.

102.94.text:
THIS SACRED BIRD, THEY BELIEVED,
CLEANED THE LAND

105.81.text:
AND CARRIED SPIRITS
ON ITS WINGS.

108.64.text:
FOR MATI WAIYA,
A CEREMONIAL LEADER

111.28.text:
AND DOLPHIN DANCER
OF THE CHUMASH TRIBE,

114.21.text:
THE BATTLE TO SAVE
THE CALIFORNIA CONDOR IS

119.45.text:
HIS ORGANIZATION, CALLED
THE WISHTOYO FOUNDATION,

122.45.text:
HAS JOINED THE FIGHT TO BRING
THE LEGENDARY THUNDERBIRD

126.09.text:
BACK FROM THE BRINK
OF EXTINCTION.

128.56.text:
Waiya:
WHEN YOU THINK OF THE CONDOR

131.26.text:
AND HOW IT'S BEEN HERE
AS LONG AS THE CHUMASH PEOPLE,

135.03.text:
YOU KNOW, WE THINK OF HOW US,
AS MODERN-DAY CHUMASH PEOPLE,

141.67.text:
SO, TO SEE THE CONDORS
SOAR AGAIN, IT GIVES US HOPE.

151.52.text:
THE CONDOR IS A SYMBOL
OF CREATION AND HEALING.

154.99.text:
NOW IT'S UP TO HUMANITY
TO HEAL THE CONDOR.

160.53.text:
BIOLOGIST KELLY SORENSON
AND THE FIELD TEAM

163.93.text:
FROM THE VENTANA
WILDLIFE SOCIETY ARE

166.40.text:
OUT TO PERFORM A CHECK-UP
ON A CAPTURED CONDOR.

173.81.text: THAT WAS TRAPPED A FEW DAYS AGO

175.74.text:
SO THAT WE COULD
TAKE A BLOOD SAMPLE

178.18.text:
AND DETERMINE
IF THERE'S ANY LEAD

180.71.text: IN THE BLOOD OF THAT BIRD.

182.58.text:
Narrator: THIS X-RAY OF A DEER
SHOT BY A BULLET REVEALS

186.82.text:
LEAD FRAGMENTS VISIBLE
AS TINY, BLACK SPECKS

193.76.text:
SO THEY'RE NOT OUT THERE,
KILLING ANYTHING.

195.46.text:
THEY'RE ONLY EATING
THE REMAINS OF DEAD ANIMALS.

197.36.text:
WHEN AN ANIMAL IS SHOT
WITH A LEAD BULLET,

200.43.text:
OFTENTIMES, THOSE FRAGMENTS
WILL BE LEFT BEHIND

204.74.text:
Narrator:
SO, WHEN THESE SCAVENGERS EAT

210.44.text:
CALIFORNIA CONDORS
ONCE SCAVENGED OVER A RANGE

214.01.text:
THAT STRETCHED FROM CANADA
TO MEXICO.

217.02.text:
BUT DECADES OF HUNTING
AFTER THE GOLD RUSH

219.75.text:
AND LOSS OF WILD HABITAT DROVE
THE BIRDS NEARLY TO EXTINCTION.

224.46.text:
Sorenson:
WE'VE NOW COME TO REALIZE
THAT LEAD POISONING HAS

228.39.text:
ALSO PLAYED A SIGNIFICANT ROLE
IN THE DECLINE OF THE SPECIES.

233.23.text:
EVEN THOUGH HUNTING CONDORS
HAD BEEN BANNED,

238.64.text:
AND JUST NINE OF THOSE REMAINED
IN THE WILD.

241.24.text:
IT WAS THEN
THAT FEDERAL BIOLOGISTS MADE

244.58.text:
THE CRITICAL DECISION TO CAPTURE
THE LAST FREE CONDORS.

248.91.text:
CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAMS HAVE
PRODUCED MORE THAN 420 CONDORS

253.12.text:
IN CALIFORNIA, UTAH, ARIZONA,
AND OTHER PARTS OF THE WEST.

258.99.text:
MORE THAN 50 WILD CONDORS
HAVE DIED FROM LEAD POISONING.

265.03.text:
SCIENTISTS SAY
THE SPECIES WILL NEVER RECOVER.

268.00.text:
Sorenson: WE HAVE A FIELD CREW
THAT WORKS INCREDIBLY HARD

271.44.text:
ALL YEAR ROUND
TO CONSTANTLY MONITOR BIRDS.

275.17.text:
AND THE OTHER BIG COMPONENT
OF WHAT THEY DO IS

278.01.text:
TO TRY TO TRAP EVERY INDIVIDUAL
AT LEAST ONCE A YEAR

281.15.text: JUST SO THAT WE CAN DETERMINE

282.98.text:
IF THEY'RE SUFFERING
FROM LEAD POISONING.

285.72.text:
Narrator: TO TREAT A CONDOR
WITH LEAD POISONING REQUIRES

289.22.text:
AN AGGRESSIVE MEDICAL PROCESS
CALLED CHELATION.

293.19.text:
Sorenson: SO, WHEN LEAD ENTERS
THE BLOOD STREAM,

300.10.text:
SO, LITERALLY, WHAT HAPPENS IS
THE BIRD STARVES TO DEATH

303.24.text:
BECAUSE IT DOESN'T KNOW
THAT IT'S HUNGRY.

305.67.text:
CHELATION GRABS AHOLD
OF THAT LEAD

308.51.text:
AND THEN ALLOWS THE ANIMAL
TO EXCRETE IT OUT NATURALLY.

312.24.text:
Nava: WE NOW KNOW
THROUGH SCIENTIFIC TESTING

314.88.text:
THAT THE ISOTOPES THAT ARE FOUND
IN LEAD AMMUNITION ARE

318.18.text:
THE SAME ISOTOPES FOUND
IN THE CONDORS' BLOOD.

321.02.text:
SO NOW LET'S MOVE FROM THAT
AND WORK ON A SOLUTION.

324.89.text:
Narrator:
FORMER CALIFORNIA ASSEMBLYMAN
PEDRO NAVA WROTE A BILL

330.83.text:
IT BANNED
THE USE OF LEAD AMMUNITION

335.83.text:
FROM ROUGHLY MONTEREY
TO VENTURA COUNTY.

338.50.text:
TODAY,
THE BIRDS' RANGE IS EXPANDING,

342.24.text:
WITH SIGHTINGS OF CONDORS
IN BAY AREA COUNTIES,

344.74.text:
LIKE ALAMEDA,
SANTA CLARA, AND SAN MATEO.

350.48.text:
IN BAJA, ARIZONA,
AND SOUTHERN UTAH.

355.45.text:
THE STATE'S FIRST CONDOR CHICK
HATCHED IN THE WILD.

359.13.text:
BUT CONDORS ARE STILL DYING
FROM LEAD POISONING.

362.53.text:
AS A RESULT,
GOVERNOR JERRY BROWN SIGNED

368.67.text:
THAT BANS THE USE
OF LEAD BULLETS FOR HUNTING

372.84.text:
BUT SOME HUNTERS, SUCH AS
BILL GAINES OF SACRAMENTO,

377.48.text:
AND SEE IT AS A BURDEN
TO A COMMUNITY THAT PROVIDES

380.41.text:
AN IMPORTANT SOURCE OF FUNDING
FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION.

383.62.text:
Gaines: REVENUE GENERATED
BY THE SALE OF HUNTING LICENSES,

387.89.text:
STAMPS, TAGS,
AND THE VARIOUS OTHER PERMITS --

393.66.text:
TO THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA ALONE
FOR WILDLIFE-RELATED HABITAT.

397.90.text:
IF HUNTING GOES AWAY,
WE'RE GONNA LOSE THAT.

400.90.text:
REQUIRING NON-LEAD BULLETS
IN THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA

404.40.text:
IS GONNA PUT
AN UNNECESSARY HARDSHIP

408.14.text:
IT'S GONNA
DRIVE THE PRICE OF AMMUNITION

413.21.text:
MANY FROM THE HUNTING COMMUNITY
WON'T BE ABLE TO AFFORD THAT.

415.75.text:
Narrator:
BULLETS MADE WITH COPPER
AND OTHER NONTOXIC METALS ARE

420.02.text:
GENERALLY MORE EXPENSIVE
THAN LEAD AMMUNITION,

422.99.text:
AND THEY MAY ALSO BE
HARDER TO COME BY, GAINES SAYS.

427.73.text:
WHICH IS ARGUABLY THE MOST
COMMON CALIBER FOR BIG GAME.

431.43.text: AND, AS A RESULT, IT'S THE ONE

433.50.text:
THAT MOST LIKELY HAS
THE NONTOXIC LOADS AVAILABLE.

436.97.text:
HAD TO PAY
ABOUT TWICE THE PRICE FOR THEM,

438.70.text:
BUT I HAD TO CALL AROUND
TO FIND WHERE THEY WERE,

440.71.text: AND I COULD PICK THEM UP.

444.34.text:
TO SCALE UP THE PRODUCTION
OF NONTOXIC HUNTING AMMUNITION,

448.15.text:
THE CALIFORNIA
FISH AND GAME COMMISSION HAS

450.35.text:
UNTIL 2019 TO ENFORCE
THE LEAD-BULLET BAN.

454.59.text:
BUT GAINES WONDERS
IF THIS STATEWIDE BAN WILL

457.99.text:
ACTUALLY KEEP LEAD
OUT OF CONDORS.

462.23.text:
THAT LEAD IS POISONING
CALIFORNIA CONDORS.

464.60.text:
THE JURY IS STILL OUT,
WE BELIEVE,

466.93.text:
ON JUST WHAT THE SOURCE
OF THAT LEAD IS.

469.57.text:
THERE'S NO LEAD AMMUNITION
BEING SHOT

471.57.text:
IN THE CALIFORNIA CONDOR RANGE,
BUT THE CONDORS ARE

474.21.text:
STILL SHOWING UP
WITH LEAD POISONING.

476.61.text:
Narrator:
LEAD POISONING IS THE LEADING
CAUSE OF DEATH FOR CONDORS.

480.38.text:
AND FOR SCIENTISTS
LIKE KELLY SORENSON,

482.41.text:
THE SOURCE OF THIS LEAD
IS CLEAR.

485.02.text:
Sorenson: WE'VE FOUND EVIDENCE
OF FRAGMENTS FROM RIFLE SLUGS

489.39.text:
IN THE DIGESTIVE SYSTEM
OF CONDORS.

493.89.text:
Man: SO, THAT MEANS GOOD NEWS
AND WE CAN LET THIS GUY FREE.

504.64.text:
Narrator:
CONDOR CAMS AT THE VENTANA
WILDLIFE SOCIETY SANCTUARY

508.77.text:
IN BIG SUR AND THE SAN DIEGO ZOO
PROVIDE A WINDOW ONLINE

513.01.text:
FOR THE PUBLIC TO SEE HOW THESE
CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BIRDS LIVE

516.62.text: IN THE WILD AND IN CAPTIVITY.

518.65.text:
Sorenson:
WE WANT THE CONDORS TO BE
THE WAY THEY WERE ONCE BEFORE

523.19.text:
AND FLYING ON THEIR OWN,
BREEDING ON THEIR OWN.

527.19.text:
Waiya:
WE HONOR THE SPIRITS OF THOSE
THAT HAVE LEFT THIS WORLD,

533.63.text:
THESE MOUNTAINS AND HILLS ARE
STILL SHAPED THE SAME WAY

538.10.text:
AND, JUST LIKE THEIR ANCESTORS,
THEY'LL FIND THEIR WAY.

551.15.text:
YOU'RE GOING THROUGH,
AND IT'S DARK,

553.25.text:
AND ALL OF A SUDDEN,
I CAN SEE FISH.

554.99.text:
AND THEN I CAN SEE
THIS MOUNTAIN.

556.62.text: AND I HAVE NO DOUBT THAT I WAS

558.22.text:
ONE OF THE FIRST PEOPLE
EVER TO SEE THAT SPACE.

563.06.text:
AT THE CALIFORNIA ACADEMY
OF SCIENCES.

565.83.text:
WE HAVE THIS GREAT STAGE
WHERE WE BRING PEOPLE IN

571.40.text:
AND THE WONDERFUL THINGS
THAT ARE FOUND ON OUR PLANET.

574.61.text:
A BIG PART OF MY JOB IS
THE CARE AND THE FEEDING

576.91.text:
AND THE MANAGEMENT
OF THE LIVING COLLECTION

580.05.text:
BUT ANOTHER REALLY EXCITING PART
OF MY JOB IS

585.62.text:
THE PHILIPPINES IS
A SPECIAL PLACE.

588.55.text:
THIS LATEST EXPEDITION WAS
REALLY TO DOCUMENT

592.36.text:
THAT'S KNOWN AS
THE VERDE ISLAND PASSAGE.

595.59.text:
IT SEEMS TO BE THE PLACE THAT
HAS MORE SPECIES IN THE OCEAN

603.94.text:
I THINK WE TOPPED OUT
AT NEARLY 70 PARTICIPANTS.

606.74.text:
AND NOT ALL THOSE ARE
ACADEMY SCIENTISTS.

608.87.text:
WE ALSO HAD FILIPINO PROFESSORS,
COLLABORATORS,

613.81.text:
A WIDE RANGE OF PEOPLE
REPRESENTING DIFFERENT FUNCTIONS

621.35.text:
ONE OF THE THINGS
THAT MADE THIS TRIP DIFFERENT

623.09.text:
AND MORE EXCITING WAS
THAT WE WERE DOING EXPLORATION

626.06.text:
IN WHAT WE CALL
THE TWILIGHT ZONE,

629.86.text:
WHICH ARE FOUND TYPICALLY
BELOW THE DEPTHS

632.97.text:
THAT YOU WOULD NORMALLY SEE
RECREATIONAL SCUBA DIVING --

640.04.text:
SO THIS AREA HAS BEEN
LARGELY UNEXPLORED.

642.74.text:
ABOUT HALF OF WHAT WE SEE IS
UNKNOWN TO SCIENCE.

648.11.text:
IN ORDER TO REACH THESE AREAS,
WE'RE USING A TECHNOLOGY

653.99.text:
WE ALSO BREATHE
VERY SPECIALIZED GAS,

657.89.text:
WHICH IS A MIX OF OXYGEN,
NITROGEN, AND HELIUM

660.99.text:
SO THAT YOU DON'T GET
THE NARCOSIS.

663.76.text:
WE'RE REALLY BREATHING
SOMETHING THAT'S ON THE ORDER

668.43.text:
SO THE REALLY FUN PART
ABOUT THAT IS THE HELIUM VOICE

671.30.text:
WHEN YOU'RE TALKING
TO EACH OTHER AT 300 FEET.

683.78.text:
TO BE A PART
OF ONE OF THESE TEAMS

685.62.text:
THAT'S STARTING TO DO
SOME OF THIS EXPLORATION

687.99.text:
AND AT A TIME
WHEN IT'S SO CRITICAL

689.76.text:
UNDERSTANDING WHAT'S GOING ON
WITH THE HEALTH OF OUR OCEANS.

714.58.text:
IT DRAWS US INTO ITS EMBRACE,
AT ONCE FAMILIAR AND ELUSIVE.

719.22.text:
Walker:
SLEEP IS REALLY ONE OF THE LAST
GREAT SCIENTIFIC MYSTERIES.

722.79.text:
WE'RE REALLY AT A REVOLUTIONARY
STAGE IN SCIENCE

725.32.text:
WHERE WE HAVE
SOME WONDERFUL TECHNOLOGIES

727.56.text:
TO HELP US
PERHAPS FOR THE FIRST TIME

733.47.text:
SLEEP SEEMS TO BE PRESENT
IN EVERY ANIMAL ORGANISM

738.90.text:
AND THE FACT THAT IT IS
SO COMMON ACROSS ALL SPECIES

743.24.text:
TELLS US IT MUST BE
CRITICALLY IMPORTANT,

746.91.text:
AT THE MOST BASIC
OF BIOLOGICAL LEVELS.

749.55.text:
Narrator:
OUR NEED FOR SLEEP IS REGULATED
BY A CIRCADIAN, OR DAILY,

754.12.text:
MASTER CLOCK THAT CAUSES US
TO FEEL

756.62.text:
MORE AWAKE DURING THE DAY
AND SLEEPY AT NIGHT.

759.76.text:
HUMANS ARE THE ONLY SPECIES
THAT WILL INTENTIONALLY FIGHT

766.00.text:
USUALLY TO MEET THE DEMANDS
OF OUR FAST-PACED LIVES.

769.34.text:
Man:
I CAN'T OPERATE WITHOUT COFFEE.

771.54.text:
Woman: I WISH I ACTUALLY COULD
SLEEP MORE,

773.71.text: BUT I BASICALLY WORK A LOT.

775.07.text:
Woman #2: AND I KNOW
WHEN I DON'T GET ENOUGH,

777.11.text: I'M REALLY CRABBY THE NEXT DAY.

778.48.text:
Narrator: BUT HOW MUCH
DOES OUR MOOD REALLY SUFFER

783.55.text:
THIS QUESTION KEEPS SOME PEOPLE
UP AT NIGHT,

785.68.text:
LIKE MATT WALKER
AND HIS STUDENTS.

788.42.text:
Walker: SO, WE DEPRIVED PEOPLE
OF A NIGHT OF SLEEP

790.49.text:
OR WE GAVE THEM
A FULL NIGHT OF SLEEP,

792.52.text:
AND THEN WE PLACED THEM INSIDE
THE MRI SCANNER,

795.13.text:
AND WE SHOWED THEM
INCREASINGLY NEGATIVE

802.77.text:
WILDLY EXAGGERATED ACTIVITY
IN THE AMYGDALA,

806.64.text:
Walker: WITHOUT SLEEP,
IT'S AS THOUGH

808.61.text:
YOU'RE ALL EMOTIONAL GAS PEDAL
AND NO BRAKE,

811.94.text: AND WE THINK THIS MAY EXPLAIN

813.55.text:
WHY THERE'S
SUCH A STRONG RELATIONSHIP

815.78.text:
BETWEEN EMOTIONAL PROBLEMS
IN PSYCHIATRIC DISORDERS

819.29.text:
THAT HAVE SLEEP PROBLEMS
ASSOCIATED WITH THEM.

822.45.text:
Narrator: TO GRASP
THE COMPLEX FUNCTIONS OF SLEEP,

825.36.text:
IT HELPS TO UNDERSTAND
THE DYNAMIC JOURNEY

827.86.text:
YOUR SLEEPING BRAIN TAKES
THROUGH THE NIGHT.

834.57.text:
THE PRINCIPAL STAGE
FROM WHICH WE DREAM.

842.07.text:
NON-R.E.M. SLEEP IS SUBDIVIDED
INTO FOUR STAGES,

845.88.text:
FROM THE LIGHTER STAGES
TO THE DEEP, RESTORATIVE STAGES.

850.45.text:
Walker:
THESE TWO TYPES OF SLEEP WILL
ESSENTIALLY PLAY OUT

854.09.text:
IN A BATTLE FOR BRAIN DOMINATION
THROUGHOUT THE NIGHT.

857.16.text:
AND WHAT THAT CREATES IS
WHAT WE CALL A SLEEP CYCLE.

861.13.text:
Narrator: BY TRACKING CHANGES
IN ELECTRICAL ACTIVITY,

864.13.text:
SCIENTISTS HAVE FOUND
CONNECTIONS BETWEEN SLEEP

869.67.text:
WALKER AND HIS TEAM THINK
THEY MAY HAVE DISCOVERED

872.67.text:
THE MECHANISM
BY WHICH THE BRAIN CREATES

877.34.text:
Walker: IT'S ALMOST AS THOUGH
YOUR LEARNING SYSTEM IS LIKE

884.52.text:
WE'RE ACQUIRING
LOTS OF INFORMATION RAPIDLY.

887.49.text: WE THINK THAT SLEEP IS A TIME

889.72.text:
WHERE THOSE FILES THAT ARE
LODGED IN THE USB STICK,

895.19.text:
ARE ACTUALLY EXPORTED OUT TO
THE HARD DRIVE OF OUR BRAIN --

899.46.text:
WHICH IS
A STRUCTURE CALLED THE CORTEX.

904.24.text:
IN THIS LARGE STORAGE SPACE
OF THE CORTEX.

908.44.text:
THAT WHEN WE WAKE UP
THE NEXT DAY,

910.34.text:
OUR USB STICK HAS NOW BEEN
CLEARED OUT,

913.15.text:
SO WE CAN START TO LEARN
NEW INFORMATION ANEW.

916.35.text:
Narrator:
THE SLEEPING BRAIN ALSO FILTERS
INFORMATION AS IT STORES IT,

920.89.text:
ALLOWING US TO FORGET
AS WELL AS TO REMEMBER.

924.22.text:
A LACK OF SLEEP ALSO AFFECTS
OUR PHYSICAL HEALTH,

927.49.text:
CONTRIBUTING TO WEIGHT GAIN
AND IMPAIRING THE IMMUNE SYSTEM.

930.66.text:
SLEEP'S VITAL ROLE IN HEALTH IS
PUSHING SCIENTISTS TO EXPLORE

935.47.text:
SOME OF THE MANY MYSTERIES
OF THE SLEEPING BRAIN.

941.87.text:
Narrator: AT THE STANFORD CENTER
FOR SLEEP SCIENCES,

944.08.text:
DR. EMMANUEL MIGNOT IS HOPING
TO SHED LIGHT

946.81.text:
ON COMMON SLEEP PROBLEMS
BY EXAMINING A RARE DISORDER -

950.15.text:
WITH A LITTLE HELP
FROM MAN'S BEST FRIEND.

955.95.text:
WHEN HE'S EXCITED,
HE HAS MOMENTARY PARALYSIS,

958.92.text:
WHICH ALSO OCCURS IN PEOPLE
WITH NARCOLEPSY,

961.53.text:
A BRAIN DISORDER THAT CAUSES
PEOPLE TO SUDDENLY FALL ASLEEP.

965.93.text:
Mignot:
WE FOUND THE CAUSE OF NARCOLEPSY

968.17.text:
BY STUDYING THE GENETIC FORM
OF NARCOLEPSY IN DOGS,

970.94.text:
AND BY SEARCHING THE GENE
FOR NARCOLEPSY.

974.21.text:
IT WAS A MUTATION
IN THE RECEPTOR

980.45.text:
WE IMMEDIATELY LOOKED IN HUMANS
IF HYPOCRETIN WAS ABNORMAL.

983.58.text:
Narrator: IT WAS ABNORMAL,
BUT THE CAUSE WAS DIFFERENT.

988.22.text:
THE CULPRIT IS
THE BODY'S OWN IMMUNE SYSTEM.

991.96.text:
IN FIGHTING OFF
A CHILDHOOD INFECTION,

994.46.text:
THE IMMUNE SYSTEM MISTAKENLY
ATTACKS THE BRAIN CELLS

998.90.text:
Mignot:
AND WHEN THEY ARE DESTROYED,

1000.93.text:
YOU CAN'T STAY AWAKE
FOR A LONG PERIOD OF TIME.

1002.83.text:
Narrator: A LANDMARK 2013 STUDY
FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF ROCHESTER

1013.28.text:
Walker:
WHAT THEY WERE DOING WAS
STUDYING THE BRAIN CELLS OF MICE

1016.78.text:
WHEN THEY WERE AWAKE
AND WHEN THEY WERE ASLEEP.

1019.62.text:
AND WHAT THEY FOUND WAS
THAT WHEN THE MICE WERE ASLEEP,

1023.39.text: THE CELLS INSIDE OF THE BRAIN

1025.42.text:
STARTED TO PHYSICALLY SHRINK
IN THEIR SIZE.

1029.36.text:
IN FACT, UP TO 60% REDUCTION
WAS OBSERVED

1032.90.text:
IN TERMS
OF THE MASS OF THESE CELLS.

1036.10.text:
Narrator:
THE SLEEPING BRAIN IS THEN ABLE
TO BATHE ITSELF

1039.71.text:
IN A CLEANSING SOLUTION
OF CEREBROSPINAL FLUID,

1044.58.text:
THAT BUILD UP
WHILE WE ARE AWAKE.

1047.01.text:
Walker:
IF THOSE TOXINS HANG AROUND
FOR TOO LONG,

1049.98.text:
NOT ONLY CAN THEY DISRUPT
THE ACTIVITY OF OUR BRAIN CELLS,

1053.35.text:
BUT THEY COULD ALSO KILL
OUR BRAIN CELLS.

1062.16.text:
AND THE REASON THAT PROTEIN IS
IMPORTANT IS

1064.50.text:
BECAUSE WE KNOW IT MAY BE
ONE OF THE TRIGGERS

1068.20.text:
AND THEY FOUND THAT THERE WERE
SIGNIFICANT REDUCTIONS,

1071.90.text:
SIGNIFICANT REMOVAL BENEFITS
OF THAT NASTY PROTEIN

1076.37.text:
Narrator:
THE BUILDUP OF BRAIN TOXINS

1080.05.text:
TAKES AN EVEN GREATER TOLL
AS WE AGE.

1083.25.text:
Walker:
OUR SLEEP STARTS TO DETERIORATE.

1090.96.text:
RELATIVE TO WHEN WE WERE
18 YEARS OLD.

1094.59.text:
WE NOW THINK
THAT IT'S NOT THAT OLDER PEOPLE

1099.06.text:
IT'S SIMPLY THAT THE BRAIN IS
UNABLE TO GENERATE

1103.80.text:
Narrator: FOR THOSE OF US
WHO CAN'T SUCCUMB TO SLEEP,

1108.71.text:
Walker: THERE'S SOME EVIDENCE
THAT IT MAY ACTUALLY NOT BE

1111.51.text:
NATURALISTIC SLEEP
THAT THOSE DRUGS PROVIDE.

1114.58.text:
WHAT WE ACTUALLY DON'T KNOW
RIGHT NOW IS

1117.55.text:
WHETHER THE TRUE
ELECTRICAL ACTIVITY THAT HAPPENS

1122.85.text:
MIMICKED AND ENHANCED
BY THOSE DRUGS.

1127.96.text:
THE RECOMMENDED 7 1/2 TO 8 HOURS
OF SLEEP PER NIGHT,

1131.70.text:
EXPERTS SUGGEST SLEEPING
IN A QUIET, COOL ROOM

1136.94.text:
AND, MOST IMPORTANTLY,
MAKING SLEEP A PRIORITY.

1140.74.text:
Walker:
WE TREAT SLEEP LIKE A LUXURY

1143.44.text:
THAT WE CAN CHOOSE
OR CHOOSE NOT TO ENGAGE IN,

1148.58.text:
SO I THINK IT'S PERHAPS TIME
THAT WE WAKE UP --

1151.75.text:
EXCUSE THE PUN --
TO THE IMPORTANCE OF SLEEP.

1168.90.text:
Marcy: DOES HE KNOW
THE NEXT STAR ALREADY?

1170.70.text:
Weiss: NOT YET.
WE STILL HAVE ONE MORE HERE.

1172.37.text:
Marcy:
YEAH, I KNOW, BUT HE NEEDS
TO KNOW THE NEXT STAR

1174.51.text: SO WE CAN GET GOING ON IT.

1178.21.text:
Marcy:
IT'S A LITTLE EMBARRASSING
HOW MANIC WE ARE.

1183.11.text:
AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA,
BERKELEY,

1185.18.text:
ARE CONNECTED REMOTELY
TO THE KECK TELESCOPE IN HAWAII.

1188.45.text: IT'S ONE OF THE WORLD'S LARGEST,

1190.72.text:
AND A NIGHT OF LOOKING
AT THE STARS COSTS $50,000.

1195.43.text:
Weiss: OKAY, GARY,
I'VE SELECTED THE NEXT TARGET.

1199.46.text:
THEY COMMUNICATE
WITH THE TELESCOPE OPERATOR

1201.63.text:
THROUGH A VIDEO CAMERA
AND A COMPUTER SCREEN.

1204.34.text:
Marcy:
FROM THE TIME THE SUN SETS TILL
THE MOMENT WHEN THE SUN RISES,

1210.28.text:
WE JUST MAKE SURE THE TELESCOPE
IS POINTED AT ONE STAR

1219.55.text:
AND GRADUATE STUDENT
LAUREN WEISS ARE USING

1221.59.text:
THE KECK TELESCOPE
TO SEARCH FOR PLANETS

1224.29.text:
OUTSIDE OUR SOLAR SYSTEM,
TRILLIONS OF MILES AWAY.

1227.53.text:
THESE EXOPLANETS REMAINED
ELUSIVE FOR DECADES.

1246.38.text: THERE IT IS. LOOK AT THAT.

1249.38.text:
Marcy: THAT'S THE INNER
AND THEN THE OUTER.

1251.25.text:
WE'RE GONNA BE NAILING DOWN
THIS OUTER PLANET.

1254.52.text:
Marcy:
SO, THIS STAR HAS TWO PLANETS --

1256.85.text:
AN INNER PLANET THAT TAKES
10 DAYS TO GO AROUND THE STAR.

1260.89.text:
AND WE'RE JUST NOW SENSING
THAT IS HAS AN OUTER PLANET

1263.76.text:
THAT'S THREE TIMES THE MASS
OF JUPITER,

1266.16.text:
AND WE'RE WATCHING THE STAR
WOBBLE AROUND

1269.07.text:
AS THESE PLANETS YANK
ON THE STAR GRAVITATIONALLY.

1272.50.text:
Narrator: EXOPLANETS EXERT
A GRAVITATIONAL PULL

1277.64.text:
JUST AS EARTH PULLS ON ITS STAR,
THE SUN.

1280.68.text:
SCIENTISTS DISCOVER EXOPLANETS
BY MEASURING A STAR'S LIGHT

1284.28.text:
AS IT'S BEING YANKED AT
BY ITS ORBITING PLANET.

1287.99.text:
Fischer:
THE TECHNIQUE THAT WE USE
TO FIND EXTRASOLAR PLANETS

1292.12.text: AND IT MAKES USE OF THE FACT

1294.26.text:
THAT WHENEVER YOU MEASURE
LIGHT WAVES,

1296.26.text:
IF THE OBJECT IS MOVING
TOWARD YOU,

1298.66.text:
THOSE WAVES APPEAR TO BE
SHORTENED.

1300.30.text:
AS THE OBJECT IS MOVING
AWAY FROM YOU,

1302.53.text:
THE WAVE APPEARS TO BE
LENGTHENED.

1305.90.text:
THESE PERIODIC CHANGES
IN THE WAVELENGTH,

1308.91.text:
AND NIGHT AFTER NIGHT,
YEAR AFTER YEAR,

1312.04.text: WE MAP OUT CHANGES IN VELOCITY.

1314.38.text:
Marcy:
DEVELOPING THAT TECHNIQUE TOOK
12 YEARS,

1317.05.text:
AND WE FOUND NO PLANETS AT ALL
DURING THAT DEVELOPMENT PERIOD,

1324.69.text:
THE DOPPLER METHOD STARTED
PAYING OFF.

1328.03.text:
A SWISS TEAM,
FOLLOWED BY MARCY'S OWN TEAM,

1334.73.text:
Marcy: WE FOUND MANY, MANY
JUPITER-SIZED PLANETS.

1338.37.text:
WE THEN FOUND THE FIRST SATURN-,
NEPTUNE-,

1346.74.text:
BUT I HAVE NO DOUBT
THAT THERE ARE

1348.75.text:
SMALLER PLANETS OUT THERE
YET TO BE DETECTED

1351.22.text:
THAT OUR CURRENT TECHNOLOGY
SIMPLY CAN'T FIND.

1353.75.text:
Man: ZERO, AND LIFTOFF
OF THE DELTA II ROCKET

1358.19.text:
ON A SEARCH FOR PLANETS
IN SOME WAY LIKE OUR OWN.

1363.30.text:
Narrator: A HUGE BREAKTHROUGH
IN THE SEARCH FOR EXOPLANETS

1369.27.text:
WHEN NASA LAUNCHED
THE KEPLER TELESCOPE INTO SPACE.

1374.87.text:
IN A CONSTELLATION
OF OUR MILKY WAY GALAXY

1381.21.text:
IT FOUND PLANETS BY LOOKING
FOR SIGNS THAT THEY WERE

1384.68.text:
CROSSING IN FRONT OF THEIR STARS
AND REDUCING THEIR BRIGHTNESS.

1388.75.text:
Marcy: IF A DARK PLANET CROSSES
IN FRONT OF A BRIGHT GLOBE,

1392.62.text:
IT'S GONNA BLOCK
A LITTLE OF THE STARLIGHT.

1395.29.text:
Narrator:
KEPLER HAS A SPECIAL MISSION --

1398.03.text:
TO FIND PLANETS SIMILAR IN SIZE
AND TEMPERATURE TO OUR OWN.

1401.77.text:
JUST HOW MANY
OF THESE EARTH-LIKE PLANETS

1404.90.text:
MIGHT BE OUT THERE CAME
AS A SHOCKING REVELATION

1408.44.text:
IN 2013, WHEN MARCY'S TEAM
PRESENTED ITS ESTIMATE.

1412.14.text:
Marcy:
WE FOUND IN THE END THAT ABOUT
ONE OUT OF FIVE SUN-LIKE STARS

1417.88.text:
HAS AN EARTH-SIZED PLANET
FAR ENOUGH FROM THE STAR

1422.65.text:
SO THAT IT WOULD BE SUITABLE
FOR WATER IN LIQUID FORM.

1426.73.text: 40 BILLION EARTH-SIZED PLANETS AT HABITABLE TEMPERATURES.

1433.26.text:
THIS IS
A REALLY INTERESTING ONE.

1435.60.text:
Narrator:
NOW THE TASK IS TO FIND OUT

1437.87.text:
HOW MANY OF THESE
EARTHLIKE PLANETS

1442.37.text:
BY WATCHING HOW HARD PLANETS
PULL AT THEIR STARS,

1446.44.text:
MARCY AND HIS TEAM CAN
FIGURE OUT WHICH ONES ARE

1449.35.text:
MASSIVE ENOUGH
TO HAVE A ROCKY SURFACE

1451.72.text:
WHERE WATER COULD POOL
AND ALLOW LIFE TO DEVELOP.

1456.65.text:
Marcy: THE QUESTION OF OTHER
INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE

1462.69.text:
AND I THINK MOST OF US HAVE
A SPLIT BRAIN ABOUT THE ANSWER.

1468.23.text:
SURELY OUR UNIVERSE IS
FILLED WITH OTHER SPECIES

1477.31.text:
AND PONDER THEIR PLACE
IN THE UNIVERSE.

1480.88.text:
ON THE OTHER HAND,
IT'S VERY MYSTERIOUS

1483.85.text:
AND A LITTLE BIT FRIGHTENING
THAT WE HAVE SEEN

1487.25.text:
NO DEFINITIVE SIGNS OF THESE
OTHER ADVANCED CIVILIZATIONS

1496.63.text:
MAYBE ADVANCED TECHNOLOGICAL
LIFE POSES A THREAT TO ITSELF,

1503.87.text: DUE TO THE WEAPONS IT DEVELOPS,

1505.94.text:
THE ABILITY TO CHANGE
THE GLOBAL ENVIRONMENT.

1509.47.text:
Woman: EVIDENCE OF SMOKE WALLS
FROM THE BURNING OIL

1514.71.text:
Marcy: SO PERHAPS THOSE
PAST CIVILIZATIONS

1517.58.text:
THAT DIDN'T MAKE IT ARE
SENDING A VERY POIGNANT MESSAGE

1521.22.text:
TELLING US TO TAKE CARE
OF OUR PLANET

1572.74.text: Announcer: SUPPORT FOR "QUEST" IS PROVIDED BY...

1598.10.text:
"QUEST" IS A PROJECT
OF KQED SCIENCE.
